text: BACKGROUND : Retinoic acid ( RA ) has important immune - modulating effects on both T and B cell function .
Our laboratory has shown that RA can enhance in vitro polyclonal B cell immunoglobulin ( Ig ) response .
Investigating cytokines known to affect B cell differentiation , we have recently shown that <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production is augmented by RA .

text: In the present study we have examined the immune modulating effects of RA on <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , another important cytokine for B cell immunoglobulin production , the expression of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> receptors on T cells , and the RA nuclear receptors .

text: METHODS : Purified T cells were obtained from adenoidal tissues , and incubated with RA ( 10 ( -7 ) M ) or DMSO solvent / media control for 0 , 6-8 , and 24 h . text: CONCLUSION : These studies suggest that RA can augment <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA production by T cells with a possible paracrine effect on <extra_id_0> IL-2R-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression .

Thus , <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may be another important cytokine modulated by RA in the immune response .
